More than forty candidates attended the baseball organization
meeting, held Friday afternoon in
the lecture hall of the Civil Engineering Building, and about the
same number answered Captain
Littman's call and came out for
the first practice of the year on
Saturday afternoon.
Littman opened the meeting by
discussing the prospects for a
good team this year, and urged
everyone present to attend practice regularly. He stated that the
old cage on Howard street had
been given up for early practice,
and that the balloon shed at Homewood would be used for this purpose,also announcing that the team
would practice on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday afternoons. Manager Richard Field
then briefly outlined the schedule
for this spring, stating, however,
that it was not yet ready for publication.
Athletic Director B. R. Murphy,
the last speaker on the program,
discussed the advantage. of early
practice in the balloon shed over
that in the cage, and urged the
men to attend practice regularly.
He stated that efforts were being
made to secure an alumnus to
coach the team this spring, but
until one could be gotten he would
assist Captain Littman in coaching the men.
The first practice was held Saturday afternoon in the balloon
shed. There promises to be a hot
fight for the first-base job this
year. Purcell, who took care of
the initial station in the majority
of the games last year, is back at
the Medical School, while Egerton,
who covered first several years
ago, has been mustered out of service and is also at the Medical
School. Sickel is out for this position again this year. Judefind,
who has been pitching for Hopkins for three years, also has announced his candidacy for first.
He suffered with a sore arm after
winning the first game of the season from Maryland State last
year, and is afraid that. his arm
will again go bad if he attempts
to twirl this season. In addition
to these men, there are a number
of new men who are candidates for
first. The most promising of these
are John Benson, Duffy,' who
played first for Marston's last
year; Schmidt, from Mount St.
Mary's; Armstrong, Keen And
Calkins. Many other positions
will be hotly contested, as the
team has much valuable material.

A new Johns Hopkins organiza• tion will have its birth on Thursday evening, February 20 at 8
o'clock. The Round Table Group
for the discussion of social problems is a direct result of Dr.
Richard W. Hogue's challenging
message to young college men, issued at the Y. M. C. A. forum of
last week. A number of students
asked Dr. Hogue if he would, undertake the formation and leadership of a class to discuss the actual problems of everyday sociology. Dr. Hogue not only consented to lead such a class, but
enthusiastically welcomed the opportunity. The group intends to
meet every Thursday evening from
8 to 9.30 o'clock in the Barn. All
earnest students are invited to
join this vitalizing, animating
course. It is, indeed,"a rare opportunity to be able to come into
close contact with a man of Dr.
Hogue's intellectual capabilities
and sincere and fearless enthusiasm.

EXERCISES TO BE AT McCOY HALL
Commemoration Day Will Be Observed
February 22— Undergraduates to
Assemble on Third Floor.

The forty-third anniversary of
the opening of Johns Hopkins University will be publicly observed
on Saturday, February 22, in McCoy Hall, the exercises beginning
at 11 A. M. The address will be
delivered by George E. Vincent,
Ph. D., LL. D., President of the
Rockefeller Foundation. Dr. Edward H. Griffin, former dean of
the University, will make the
opening prayer.
The trustees, the faculty, the
Alumni Council and the official
guests will assemble at 10.30
o'clock in Levering Hall (first
floor), corner of Eutaw street and
Druid Hill avenue. The alumni
will assemble at 10.30 on the second floor of Levering Hall. The
students will meet at 10.20 in the
places designated below and will
proceed, under the direction of
their marshals, to the assembly
room. Graduate students in arts
and sciences will meet on the second floor of McCoy Hall, at the
south end. Students of medicine
will meet on the second floor of
McCoy Hall, at the north end, and
undergraduate students on the
third floor of McCoy Hall.
The procession will enter the
assembly hall at 10.45. Part of
the hall will be reserved until that
time for the families of the trustees and faculty, who will be admitted by special cards. After
the procession has entered, the
remaining seats will be open to
the public, without cards of admission.
The exercises in McCoy Hall
will begin punctually at 11 o'clock
and will close probably before 1
o'clock. Every undergraduate student is expected to attend.
Out-door Practice for Runner,.

The track squad started outdoor practice last Monday. The
outdoor track is a vast improvement on the poorly kept track in
the cage, where the team has been
practicing. Coach Murphy expects
to have the old balloon shed converted into an indoor track for inclement weather. He intends to
have a plank track built, and the
shed lengthened hence, it will be
an ideal place for the inter-class
meets.
The team is rapidly rounding
into form in preparation for the
big Armory Meet, to be held under the management of the Second
Regiment. The relay team will
probably run against Georgetown,
Maryland State and University of
Virginia. At this meet several
South Atlantic events will be
staged, and all men who come out
regularly will be entered. Captain Smith also stated that particular attention would be shown
any new men who would come out
and work hard.

"Is Industrial Democracy Possible?" was the subject of Thursday's Open Forum discussion by
Dr. R. W. Hogue, the leader of
the Sunday Open Forum. Dr.
Hogue said that industrial democracy, a pressing problem of
the day, was essential and that its
solution was possible and, in fact,
inevitable. The great question is,
he said, how will it be accomplished? Will it be through anarchy and revolution or can it be
evolved by peaceful means?
The speaker quoted several
magazine articles and editorials
written by members of the employing class, which pointed out that
the time has come when workers
in all branches of industry must
no longer be treated as "hands,"
but as human beings; when those
who do the lowly work, as well as
those who direct, must share in
the proceeds of their labor instead
of merely being given "wages";
when there shall be legal compulsion for children to go to school
until a certain age, preventing
their childhood being burnt out in
the forge of industry; when a sufficient wage is paid "to enable
the worker to maintain himself
and his family in health and honor, with such a margin of leisure
as will permit reasonable recreation and the development of mind
and spirit."
John D. Rockefeller, Jr., said
at a recent meeting of business
men that it was not adequate
hours or adequate wages that are
needed, but that the secret is adequate representation for labor.
This partnership between labor
and capital must not be superficial, but must be worked out
from the bottom up and must be
sincere.
When asked in what manner he
believed the change would come
about, Dr. Hogue answered that
unless measures are soon taken
along the lines of industrial democracy by the employing or
"capitalist" class, the manner in
which this ideal will come about
will be one of revolution and
force. If, however, more men like
Mr. Rockefeller sincerely have the
vision and have the courage to
act as they believe right, the
"brotherhood in industry" may be
realized without strife and with
little loss of energy.

H. Latane shows that in entering
a League of Nations, the United
States would not be disregarding
the Monroe Doctrine, but would
be extending this principle to the
whole world. Moreover, the entrance of the United States into
such a league would not be a violation of the American policy of
isolation, but in a sense would be
the extension of that principle
also to the nations of the world.
The resolutions introduced recently by Senator Knox and Senator Borah indicate that, in the

fear or threat of intervention,
domination or subjugation by
other states. * * * It will be seen

This year's Hullabaloo will differ radically from those which
have preceded it. In the first
place, it will be the University annual, and as such will represent
every class. Every student activity, whether in athletic, literary,
musical or dramatic lines, will be
recorded, and any contribution, no
matter to what class it pertains,
will be accepted, if it reaches the
required standard. In other words,
the Hullabaloo is no longer to be
solely for the Senior Class, but is
to be the mirror of University life;
and, that this end may be obtained more readily,two associate
boards have been established, upon
which the lower classes are equally represented. These representatives will attend to the literary
work and the business end of the
Hullabaloo among their respective
classes, and it is hoped that their
classmates, by means of articles,
snapshots and drawings, will help
them to make this year's annual
a complete record of. the activities of their class.
In addition to having become a
University annual, the Hullabaloo
is going to be out 012 time. Therefore, the write-ups and articles
must be in by February 15, unless
the editor-in-chief is notified and
authorizes an additional delay.
The group and individual pictures,
of which there will be an unusual
number this year, must be taken
within the specified time; and,
therefore, if any group has failed
to make arrangements with Sonneborn for their sittings, they
should do so at once. It would
also greatly facilitate matters if
the men of the various classes
ould order and pay for their
copies through their business repesentative as soon as possible.

Dr. John H. Gregory, who was
recently appointed associate professor of civil engineering, is
teaching sanitary engineering and
hydraulics. He obtained his degree .of Bachelor of Science in
civil engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston, in 1895, and has been actively engaged in sanitary engineering practice since he left college.
Dr. Gregory is particularly
qualified for teaching sanitary engineering and hydraulics by his
twenty-four years of wide and
varied experience in many of the
large cities of the United States
and Canada. Boston, Albany,
Philadelphia, Jersey City, New
York, Columbus, Montreal, Quebec and Pittsburgh are a few of
the cities where Dr. Gregory was
connected with problems of water
supply, water purification and
sewage disposal.
In 1913 he came to Baltimore
and made an investigation and report on the adequacy of the design and construction of the filtered-water reservoir and filtration plant, which was then being
built.
Dr. Gregory has studied the
water supply, water purification
and sewage disposal systems in
England, Scotland, France, Belgium, Switzerland and Germany.
Because of his unlimited knowledge of these subjects, Dr. Gregory
is considered an authority, and at
different times he has written interesting articles for engineering
magazines and delivered lectures
to various societies.

"Is Industrial Democracy Possible?" was the subject of Thursday's Open Forum discussion by
Dr. R. W. Hogue, the leader of
the Sunday Open Forum. Dr.
Hogue said that industrial democracy, a pressing problem of
the day, was essential and that its
solution was possible and, in fact,
inevitable. The great question is,
he said, how will it be accomplished? Will it be through anarchy and revolution or can it be
evolved by peaceful means?
The speaker quoted several
magazine articles and editorials
written by members of the employing class, which pointed out that
the time has come when workers
in all branches of industry must
no longer be treated as "hands,"
but as human beings; when those
who do the lowly work, as well as
those who direct, must share in
the proceeds of their labor instead
of merely being given "wages";
when there shall be legal compulsion for children to go to school
until a certain age, preventing
their childhood being burnt out in
the forge of industry; when a sufficient wage is paid "to enable
the worker to maintain himself
and his family in health and honor, with such a margin of leisure
as will permit reasonable recreation and the development of mind
and spirit."
John D. Rockefeller, Jr., said
at a recent meeting of business
men that it was not adequate
hours or adequate wages that are
needed, but that the secret is adequate representation for labor.
This partnership between labor
and capital must not be superficial, but must be worked out
from the bottom up and must be
sincere.
When asked in what manner he
believed the change would come
about, Dr. Hogue answered that
unless measures are soon taken
along the lines of industrial democracy by the employing or
"capitalist" class, the manner in
which this ideal will come about
will be one of revolution and
force. If, however, more men like
Mr. Rockefeller sincerely have the
vision and have the courage to
act as they believe right, the
"brotherhood in industry" may be
realized without strife and with
little loss of energy.

be extending this principle to the
whole world. Moreover, the entrance of the United States into
such a league would not be a violation of the American policy of

"The Monroe Doctrine was in

recorded, and any contribution, no

required standard. In other words,

to be the mirror of University life;

boards have been established, upon
which the lower classes are equally represented. These representatives will attend to the literary
work and the business end of the
Hullabaloo among their respective
classes, and it is hoped that their
classmates, by means of articles,
snapshots and drawings, will help
them to make this year's annual
a complete record of. the activities of their class.

within the specified time; and,

Dr. John H. Gregory, who was
recently appointed associate professor of civil engineering, is
teaching sanitary engineering and
hydraulics. He obtained his degree .of Bachelor of Science in

qualified for teaching sanitary engineering and hydraulics by his
twenty-four years of wide and
varied experience in many of the
large cities of the United States
and Canada. Boston, Albany,
Philadelphia, Jersey City, New
York, Columbus, Montreal, Quebec and Pittsburgh are a few of
the cities where Dr. Gregory was
connected with problems of water
supply, water purification and
sewage disposal.
In 1913 he came to Baltimore
and made an investigation and report on the adequacy of the design and construction of the filtered-water reservoir and filtration plant, which was then being
built.
Dr. Gregory has studied the
water supply, water purification
and sewage disposal systems in
England, Scotland, France, Belgium, Switzerland and Germany.
Because of his unlimited knowledge of these subjects, Dr. Gregory
is considered an authority, and at
different times he has written interesting articles for engineering
magazines and delivered lectures
to various societies.
